paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the TTR gene variants, particularly TTR V30M, and their role in ATTR amyloidosis, including penetrance data and functional studies.

patients.phenotype: ATTR amyloidosis, primarily affecting cardiac and nervous systems

individual_records.evidence_sentence: The presence of TTR fragments was observed in the heart of young and old mice but not in other tissues following SerpinA1 knockdown.
Amyloid deposits extracted from cardiac and adipose tissue specimens from ATTR V30M patients were composed of a mixture of both cleaved and full-length TTR.
In the presence of TTR fragments, particularly the 49–127 C-terminal peptide, was implicated in TTR amyloidogenesis.
The presence of TTR fragments was observed in the heart of young and old mice but not in other tissues following SerpinA1 knockdown.

functional_data.summary: TTR V30M is susceptible to plasmin-mediated proteolysis, which is partially inhibited by SerpinA1.

variants.segregation_data: Yes, segregates with disease in families.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on functional studies and clinical data.
variants.additional_notes: The study emphasizes the role of SerpinA1 in modulating TTR proteolysis and its implications for amyloidogenesis.
key_quotes: The most common TTR variant, TTR V30M, is susceptible to plasmin-mediated proteolysis.
Increased TTR deposition was found in the heart of older HM30 mice.

extraction_metadata.notes: Data was extracted thoroughly from the main text.
